Lawrence Creshkoff. WGBH-TV. Channel 2. Boston: "So fa*the reports have been
quite different and here is yet another one. In Boston we began slowly with
seven members in 1946 Qnd ran about 3 or 4 programs a week on a commercial station.
In October, 1953, we began on FM. WGBH is the station headed by Lowell Institute
and is the Massachusetts educational channel. On May 2, Channel 2 will be our
associate in TV. The most essential aspect of our organization is the number and
diversity of institutions in the group, and the fact that each program is thought
of as being put on by all the members; hence, we have good cooperation and joint
responsibility."
Hartford Gunn. WGBH-TV. Boston: "I’m director of operations at WGBH-TV and
I think Larry has told you enough about our programming already."
Charles Dudley. Emerson College. Boston. Mass.; "I’m chairman of the Department
of Broadcasting at Emerson College which is a liberal arts college with special
majors in speech. We began broadcasting about nine years ago with a 10-watt station
and now have an 1800 watt station. We started in TV two years ago with a completely
closed circuit, utilizing Dage Camera equipment. Generally, this has worked well
as a student training device."
Gordon Hendricks. New York: "I’m a new affiliate member of this organization
and have the first and only radio program on motion picture film."
Nominations for a planning committee for a proposed 1956 conference were en¬
couraged. Announcements and general orientation were given by Dr. Harry Lyle.
